instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.R6905: What is R6905? Resistor between charger voltage and input to PP3V42_G3H power supply on older Macbooks, pre-2011 models. This resistor blows when C6990 has shorted to ground or U6990 has shorted to ground, and will result in PP3V42_G3H missing and the magsafe charger not having a light since PP3V42_G3H is necessary for the SMC to turn on and the onewire circuit to turn on..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.ALL_SYS: What is ALL_SYS? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD When you see ALL_SYS, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
definitions.R7402: What is R7402? Resistor between PPVIN_S0_CPUIMVP and CPUIMVP_TON. TON stands for TIME ON â€“ CPUIMVP_TON configures the buck converter for the CPU based on its input power supply. If this resistor is blown, the machine will turn on but not have any image, chime, or POST, because CPU vcore will be missing. This resistor is often the first to corrode because it is along a high voltage rail and it is right on the edge of the board, check this on 2011-2012 model Macbook Pros that turn on and do not chime. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> keeps shorting
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> keeps shorting. I get a green flickering light on charger then it will go away <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> will short on <RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR> short goes away when removed if i replace component same thing repeats. What could be wrong?

seems like the shorting has stopped but im only getting 1.5v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuates from 15.80v to 16.80v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> keeps shorting
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> keeps shorting
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> keeps shorting
threads.message: Ummm so yeah both current sensing circuits are blown lol and likely the ISL as well. Replace current sense resistors and ISL but check that the traces are good from the ISL throughout the sense resistors or it won't fix anything.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> keeps shorting
threads.message: So replaces all the components on those circuits as well as isl and board turns on but wont charge battery.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> keeps shorting
threads.message: Does it see that battery in the OS or do you get an X in the battery? If it sees the battery, check resistance between 17/18 and 27/28 again to make sure they measure properly I suspect something may still be wrong there

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> keeps shorting
threads.message: i realized the board is powering on but its brain dead? i get no cpuvcore current sensing. Could be why its not charging but if not then Lgate on isl is only getting .600v everything else checks out.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> keeps shorting
threads.message:
ok lets see, you say:

[QUOTE="Gmorb, post: 34341"]3v42 is present
17/18=32mohm
27/28=22mohm[/QUOTE]

You mean Megaohm?? if yes, both are absolutely wrong and if you already replaced resistors the problem could be a broken trace on sense circuits,  if you mean Ohm the first is wrong the second is fine, so, what is it....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> keeps shorting
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7000</CHIP>
17/18=3.6 ohm
27/28=20.9 ohm

i think that circuit is good. the next issue i found was cpuvcore is not getting any voltage after doing some digging i found that <SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_BOOT1</SIGNAL> on <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> is only outputting 4.85v LGate and UGate output nothing. ive already tried replacing <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> but results are the same. so cpu is not powering on any help appreciated.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> keeps shorting
threads.message: You cannot just measure LGATE/UGATE, they are switching outputs and will not read anything useful on a multimeter. <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> present?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> keeps shorting
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> keeps shorting
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> keeps shorting
threads.message: yes liquid damage those resistors are fine.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> keeps shorting
threads.message: <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> is not being told to output by the CPU. Could be anything, crap under SMC, dead CPU, etc. All depends on where the liquid was.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> keeps shorting
threads.message: smc area looks the most affected by water.
